abstracts.cdata!:
The project's overall outcome is
            rated marginally satisfactory, although this rating masks
            different levels of performance among the several
            components, with land and forestry being fully satisfactory,
            public administration marginally satisfactory, and rural
            finance unsatisfactory. Key lessons learned include the
            following: Coordination with international development
            agencies can improve the chances of a project's success
            especially a project having a strong policy content.
            Although they provide significant balance of payments
            support, adjustment operations do not earmark funds to cover
            incremental costs associated with investment activities. In
            countries with severe fiscal problems, IDA should ensure
            that the implementing agencies do receive the necessary
            funds to carry out the related investments in a timely
            manner. The flexibility of action plans should be carefully
            designed. Action plans and legal agreements should include
            provisions permitting technical adjustments to targets that
            could be made during implementation without excessive
            bureaucratic requirements. It is more prudent to unbundle a
            set of reforms into smaller operations that address each
            subsector separately. It may also be apt to add a parallel
            investment project that provides the funds for the
            implementing agencies to carry out the investment activities
            associated with the adjustment operation. Lastly, an
            adjustment operation of this type can lay the policy
            framework for follow-up investment operations.
